newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks end higher, smaller firms in demand.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks end higher, smaller firms in demand.

text.p: Stocks closed higher on Wednesday for the fourth consecutive session with buying focused on recent laggards smaller-capitalised shares, brokers said.
They said manufacturing blue chips suffered from profit-taking and the yen's weakness.
"Rotational buying of blue chips came to an end. Instead, investors are seeking short-term profits from smaller-cap shares," said Ha Ki-ho of Jardine Fleming Securities.
Lee Hee-myung of Samsung Securities said: "The market seems overheated. It needs a consolidation."
The composite stock index closed at 698.66, up 3.69 points.
Brokers said the market largely ignored a proposal for short-term banking reforms by a presidential advisory panel as the move had been widely expected.
The financial sub-index fell 1.93 points to 513.16 but brokers attributed the fall to profit-taking.
Chungbuk Bank went limit-up, gaining 340 won to 4,600, on hopes the banks would be a target of merger and acquisition eventually.
Investment trust companies, major institutional buyers, accumulated chipmaking stocks in the belief a recovery was imminent for the memory chip industry.
Samsung Electronics rose 300 won to 6,450, LG Semicon 900 won to 30,600 and Hyundai Electronics 1,400 won to 41,900.
Brokers said the yen's weakness sparked worries about weakening competitiveness of Korean exporters against their Japanese rivals.
They said smaller companies would come into spotlight for the time being as investors were uncertain about the prospect for big manufacturers.
